page.title: 05Conford Moor.
page.content: Conford Moor and Passfield Common adajacent areas of National Trust also adjoin the military area, the Hollywater acting as boundary. On Conford Moor a strip of 20 hectares either side of the stream for half a mile is a Site of Special Scientific Interest. The moorland banks,typically acid, give rise to bog vegetation, plants tolerant of acid and lime hating. But water feeding the area is alkaline and so fen vegetation, with lime loving and lime tolerant plants exists alongside the bog vegetation. For reasons yet unknown the water level has fallen in recent years. On Passfield Common, once grazed, birch is being cut for broom handles. Plans are afoot to restore Hollywater Pond which dried out after its dam burst. The National Trust look to voluntary help by young people.
